id.description: This is the initial USFM marker in any scripture text file

ide.description: This marker should be used to specify the character encoding of the text within the file

sts.description: The contents of the status marker can be defined by the downstream system being used to track project status

rem.description: Used for adding brief comments by a translator, consultant, or support person

toc1.description: Not for use directly within the front matter (FRT) peripheral file

toc2.description: Not for use directly within the front matter (FRT) peripheral file

toc3.description: Not for use directly within the front matter (FRT) peripheral file

toc4.description: Not in USFM 2.4 but rather an addition used by Michael Kahunapule Johnson (Haiola/USFX)

imt.description: May be used for the introduction title or other major introduction division (rather than \is) when the introduction text contains numerous additional sub-divisions.

imq.nameEnglish: Introduction flush left (margin) quote from text paragraph

ipr.description: Typically used for a quote from text reference

ib.description: May be used to explicitly indicate additional white space between paragraphs

io.description: The outline entry typically ends with a range of references in parentheses

ior.description: An outline entry typically ends with a range of references in parentheses. This is an optional character style for marking (and potentially formatting) these references separately

iex.description: e.g. explanation of missing book in a short Old Testament

iqt.description: Scripture quotations, or other quoted text, appearing in the introduction

imte.description: Used to mark a major title indicating the end of the introduction

ie.description: Optionally included to explicitly indicate the end of the introduction material

mt.description: The key components in the title of a biblical book

mte.description: May be used in texts which repeat the main title at the end of the introduction, or to mark a major title indicating the end of the introduction. The content is not typically identical to \mt#.

ms.description: These are headings before larger text divisions than what is typically considered a "section" division (see \s#)

mr.description: The text reference range listed under a major section heading. Perhaps it could be described as the verse range which the \ms major section heading above it applies to.

sr.description: The text reference range listed under a section heading. \sr is not equivalent to \r which is used for marking parallel references. Perhaps it could be described as the verse range which the \s section heading above it applies to.

r.description: A reference to a parallel passage usually located under a section heading \s#

rq.description: A (cross) reference indicating the source text for the preceding quotation (usually an Old Testament quote). The reference(s) are intended to be formatted (typeset) within the scripture body text column, and not extracted from the text as are regular cross-references (\x…\x*). They are also typically separated from the main text of Scripture using a different type style and alignment.

d.description: Sometimes used in Psalms under the section title (e.g. "For the director of Music")

c.description: No text should follow this marker (i.e., after the chapter number? But some versions have footnotes here!

ca.description: Used for marking the chapter number used in an alternate versification scheme. Required when different versification traditions need to be supported in the same translation text.

cl.description: Used when the chosen publishing presentation will render chapter divisions as headings, and not drop cap numerals. Usage note: If \cl is entered once before chapter 1 (\c 1) it represents the text for "chapter" to be used throughout the current book. If \cl is used after each individual chapter marker, it represents the particular text to be used for the display of the current chapter heading (usually done if numbers are being presented as words, not numerals).

cp.description: This is a chapter marker (number, letter) which would be displayed in the published text (where the published marker is different than the \c # used within the translation editing environment)

cd.description: A brief description of chapter content (similar to \d - descriptive heading, or \iex - )

v.description: Marker is followed by the verse number #, and the text of the verse

va.description: Used for marking verse numbers used in an alternate versification scheme. Required when different versification traditions need to be supported in the same translation text.

vp.description: This is a verse marker (number, letter) which would be displayed in the published text (where the published marker is different than the \v # used within the translation editing environment)

p.description: Followed immediately by a space and paragraph text, or by a new line and a verse marker

m.description: No first line indent. Followed immediately by a space and paragraph text, or by a new line and a verse marker. Usually used to resume prose at the margin (without indent) after poetry or OT quotation (i.e. continuation of the previous paragraph).

pi.description:
Used in some texts for discourse sections. The variable # represents the level of indent.
        See also \pm.

nb.description:
Indicates "no-break" with previous paragraph (regardless of previous paragraph type).
        Commonly used in cases where the previous paragraph spans the chapter boundary.
        No-break markup within poetry: Some translations have a publishing tradition of inserting a small
            amount of additional white-space at chapter boundaries.
        It is important in these texts to use the b marker within any specific poetic contexts where
            no visible break in the flow of the the text is intended at a particular chapter boundary.

li.description:
An out-dented paragraph meant to highlight the items of a list.
        Lists may be used to markup the elements of a recurrent structure, such as the days within the creation account,
            or the Decalogue (10 commandments). The variable # represents the level of indent.

pr.description: "Deprecated" (i.e. use is strongly discouraged). Recommended alternate: \pmr

ph.description:
"Deprecated" (i.e. use is strongly discouraged).
        The variable # represents the level of overall paragraph indent.

b.description:
May be used to explicitly indicate additional white space between paragraphs.
        No text should follow this marker, and it should not be used before or after titles to indicate white-space.
        Also use for stanza breaks in poetry, or between poetry and prose.

q.description: The variable # represents the level of indent (i.e. \q1, \q2, \q3 etc.)

qs.description: Used for the expression "Selah" commonly found in Psalms and Habakkuk. This text is frequently right aligned, and rendered on the same line as the previous poetic text, if space allows.

qac.description: Marker to indicate the acrostic letter within a poetic line

qm.description: The variable # represents the level of indent (i.e. \qm1, \qm2 etc.)

tr.description: The first \tr initiates a new table. Rows contain column headings or cells

th.description: The variable # represents the table column number

thr.description: The variable # represents the table column number

tc.description: The variable # represents the table column number. An empty table cell still requires a corresponding marker in the table text.

tcr.description: The variable # represents the table column number. An empty table cell still requires a corresponding marker in the table text.

f.description: Footnotes are entered inline within the main scripture body text. The boundaries of the footnote text are defined by an opening and closing marker.

e.description: Endnotes are entered inline within the main scripture body text. The boundaries of the endnote text are defined by an opening and closing marker.

fr.description: This is the chapter and verse(s) that note refers to. Chapter and verse numbers must have a separator between them.

fk.description: The specific keyword/term from the text for which the footnote is being provided.

fq.description: A quotation from the current scripture text translation for which the note is being provided. Longer quotations are sometimes shortened using an ellipsis (i.e. suspension dots "…"). Many existing translation texts have marked both quotations from the existing translation text, as well as alternative translations, using \fq. An additional marker – \fqa – is provided for marking alternative translations, and can be used to distinguish between quotations and alternatives.

fqa.description: Used to distinguish between a quotation of the current scripture text translation, and an alternate translation

fl.description: Can be used for marking or "labeling" a word or words which are used consistently across certain types of translation notes (such as the words "Or" in an alternative translation note, "Others", "Heb.", "LXX" etc.)

fp.description: Use this marker to if you need to indicate the start of a new paragraph within a footnote (uncommon in standard Bible notes)

fv.description: To mark the location of a verse number in the the text quotation or alternative translation

fn.description: To mark the location of a sequential footnote number in the the text quotation or alternative translation

ft.description: The essential (explanatory) text of the footnote

fdc.description: Text between these markers is material to be included only in published editions that contain the Deuterocanonical books.

fm.description: Used where two or more locations in the scripture text should ideally refer the reader to the same footnote text (as seen in identical footnote text which is referred to at Gen 2.9 and Gen 2.17 in some English translations). Because the nature of this marker is related directly to the published form of the text, it is not intended for use in scripture authoring. It may be used during the publishing process to connect two callers to the same footnote text.

x.description: Cross-references are entered inline within the main scripture body text. The boundaries of the cross-reference text are defined by an opening and closing marker.

xo.description: This is the chapter and verse(s) that note refers to. Chapter and verse numbers must have a separator between them.

xk.description: A keyword from the scripture translation text which the target reference(s) also refer to

xq.description: A quotation from the scripture text. Use of a quotation would be intended to help the reader to understand the portion of text (or concept) for which the target reference(s) are being supplied.

xt.description: The list of target scripture locations being provided as alternate references to the text (or concept) of the origin reference. This is a list of book name abbreviations and chapter + verse references, separated by semicolons (though there may be an alternate references format for this list in different areas and countries).

xot.description: References (or other text) between these markers is material to be included only in published editions that contain the Old Testament books. (optional)

xnt.description: References (or other text) between these markers is material to be included only in published editions that contain the New Testament books. (optional)

xdc.description: References (or other text) between these markers is material to be included only in published editions that contain the Deuterocanonical books. (optional)

add.description: A translator's explanation; words added by the translator for clarity – text which is not literally a part of the original language, but which was supplied to make the meaning of the original clear

dc.description: Deuterocanonical/LXX additions or insertions in the Protocanonical text

lit.description: e.g. a guide which tells the reader/worshipper that he should recite a prayer or recitation etc.

qt.description: Old Testament quotations in the New Testament, or other quotations

sig.description: of the author of an epistle/letter

sls.description: Passage of text based on a secondary language or alternate text source. E.g. The NBS02 has large sections of text in EZR and DAN in italics, to represent where the original text is in Aramaic, not Hebrew.

ndx.description: Surround word(s) with this markup to indicate that it should appear in the subject index

w.description: Surround word(s) with this markup to indicate that it should appear in the word list

wg.description: Surround word(s) with this markup to indicate that it should appear in the Greek word list

wh.description: Surround word(s) with this markup to indicate that it should appear in the Hebrew word list

ef.description: Extended footnotes (for study Bibles) are entered inline within the main scripture body text. The boundaries of the footnote text are defined by an opening and closing marker.

fs.description: "Deprecated" (i.e. use is strongly discouraged). A summary text for the concept/idea/quotation from the current Scripture text translation for which the note is being provided.

ex.description: Extended cross-references (for study Bibles) are entered inline within the main scripture body text. The boundaries of the cross-reference text are defined by an opening and closing marker.

esb.description: In study Bibles. Finishes at next \esb marker or at end of chapter.

cat.description: Categories can optionally be assigned to extended study notes or sidebars by supplying a category tag (name) inside of opening and closing \cat … \cat* markers. Category tags should be restricted to alpha-numeric characters. A list of category tags are defined individually and uniquely for each study Bible project.

pdi.description: "Deprecated" (i.e. use is strongly discouraged) in 2004 for USFM 2.0. Substituted with embedded text markup.

pde.description: "Deprecated" (i.e. use is strongly discouraged) in 2004 for USFM 2.0. Substituted with embedded text markup.

wr.description: "Deprecated" (i.e. use is strongly discouraged) in 2004 for USFM 2.0. Was really a duplicate of \w … \w* used for marking words in the Scripture text which are included in the wordlist.

ps.description: "Deprecated" (i.e. use is strongly discouraged) in 2004 for USFM 2.0. This was used in conjunction with \nb to indicate that the paragraph spans the chapter boundary. It should be sufficient to just start the new chapter with \nb and use the appropriate paragraph marker for the previous chapter (\p, \m, etc.).
